title: 103_s1952
content:
The United States Botanic Garden Commemorative Coin Act of 1995 is cited in Section 1. Section 2 outlines the specifications of the coin. The Secretary of the Treasury shall issue not more than 500,000 $1 silver coins, weighing 26.73 grams, with a diameter of 1.5 inches, containing 90% silver and 10% copper. The design of the coins shall feature a rose, the national floral emblem, and a frontal view of the French facade of the United States. The $1 silver coins issued under this Act shall bear inscriptions of the year '1995', 'Liberty', 'In God We Trust', 'United States of America', and 'E Pluribus Unum'. These coins shall be legal tender as provided in section 5103 of title 31, United States Code. The Secretary shall obtain silver for the coins minted under this Act only from stockpiles established under the Strategic and Critical Materials Stock Piling Act. Selection of design for the coins. The design for the coins authorized by this Act shall be selected by the Secretary after consultation with the National Fund for the United States Botanic Garden and the Commission of Fine Arts. The design shall also be reviewed by the Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee. Issuance of coins. The Act authorizes the issuance of coins in uncirculated and proof qualities, minted at a designated Mint facility. The Secretary may issue coins under this Act from January 1, 1995, to December 31, 1995. Additionally, only one Mint facility in the United States can strike coins of a specific quality under this Act. The coins authorized under this Act shall be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the face value of the coins, plus a surcharge. Bulk sales will be available at a reasonable discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted by the Secretary. Prepaid orders for authorized coins shall be accepted prior to issuance at a reasonable discount. Sales under this subsection will include a required surcharge of $10 per coin. General waiver of procurement regulations. No law governing procurement or public contracts applies to the procurement of goods or services necessary for carrying out the provisions of this Act. This section does not exempt anyone entering into a contract under this Act from complying with any law related to equal employment opportunity. Distribution of surcharges. Distribution of surcharges received by the Secretary from the sale of coins issued under this Act shall be promptly paid by the Secretary to the National Fund for the United States Botanic Garden. The Comptroller General has the right to examine the books, records, documents, and other data of the National Fund for the United States Botanic Garden related to the expenditures of amounts paid under section 8. The Act is titled the "United States Botanic Garden Commemorative Coin Act of 1995". Coin specifications are outlined in the Act. The Act titled the "United States Botanic Garden Commemorative Coin Act of 1995" authorizes the minting of up to 500,000 $1 coins with a design featuring a rose and the US Botanic Garden facade. The coins will weigh 26.73 grams, have a diameter of 1.500 inches, and contain 90% silver and 10% copper. They will bear inscriptions including "Liberty", "In God We Trust", and "E Pluribus Unum", and be legal tender. All coins minted under the "United States Botanic Garden Commemorative Coin Act of 1995" shall be considered numismatic items under section 5134 of title 31, United States Code. The Secretary will obtain silver for coins from stockpiles under the Strategic and Critical Materials Stock Piling Act. The design will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with the National Fund for the United States Botanic Garden and the Commission of Fine Arts, and reviewed by the Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee for coins minted under this Act. SEC. 5. ISSUANCE OF COINS.

Coins minted under this Act may be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities at a single designated Mint facility from January 1, 1995, to December 31, 1995.

SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS. The coins authorized under this Act will be sold by the Secretary at a price including the face value, a surcharge, and the cost of designing and issuing the coins. Bulk sales will be available at a discount, prepaid orders will be accepted, and all sales will include a $10 surcharge per coin. SEC. 7. GENERAL WAIVER OF PROCUREMENT REGULATIONS. No procurement laws apply to goods and services for this Act, except for equal employment opportunity laws. SEC. 8. DISTRIBUTION OF SURCHARGES. Surcharges from coin sales go to the National Fund for the United States Botanic Garden. SEC. 9. AUDITS. SEC. 9. AUDITS. The Comptroller General of the United States can examine the National Fund for the United States Botanic Garden's books and records related to expenditures under section 8.
